item.title: First contact (science fiction)
item.description:
First Contact (Science Fiction) ðŸ”—

First contact is a recurring theme in science fiction, exploring the initial meeting between humans and extraterrestrial life or any sentient species from different planets or natural satellites. It draws parallels with the anthropological concept of first contact.

History ðŸ”—

The concept dates back to the 2nd century AD with Lucian of Samosata’s A True Story. Voltaire’s Le MicromÃ©gas (1752) features an alien from Sirius visiting Earth and engaging in philosophical discussions with humans. H.G. Wells’ The War of the Worlds is traditionally credited with popularizing the trope of conflict between humans and alien intelligent species, although earlier examples exist, such as Les XipÃ©huz.

The 1950s saw a surge in first contact stories in the United States, often reflecting Cold War anxieties about nuclear holocaust or communist invasion. Films like The Day the Earth Stood Still (1951) began to portray first contact as potentially beneficial, while Invasion of the Body Snatchers (1956) reflected fears of communist infiltration.

Arthur C. Clarke’s Childhood’s End depicts both positive and negative consequences of first contact, while StanisÅ‚aw Lem’s Solaris explores the futility of communication with extraterrestrial intelligence.

The Star Trek franchise introduced the Prime Directive, a non-interference regulation, which has since become a common trope in science fiction.

Later works include Close Encounters of the Third Kind (1977), Carl Sagan’s Contact (1985), and novels like The Sparrow (1996) and The Three-Body Problem (2006). Films like Arrival (2016) focus on the linguistic challenges of first contact. Project Hail Mary (2021) depicts an unintended first contact scenario.

Types and Themes ðŸ”—

First contact stories vary widely in their methods of contact and the nature of the subsequent interaction. These variations include positive vs. negative outcomes, physical meetings vs. message interception, and more.

Alien Invasion ðŸ”—

Alien invasion is a common early trope, popularized by The War of the Worlds. During the Cold War, these stories often reflected American anxieties about the Soviet Union, with infiltration narratives being a variation on the theme.

Alien Artifacts ðŸ”—

Bracewell probes, hypothesized by Ronald N. Bracewell, are extraterrestrial artifacts that allow real-time communication. Big Dumb Objects, such as megastructures like ringworlds, are a common variation. 2001: A Space Odyssey features mysterious black Monoliths that enhance technological progress. Stories also involve finding alien spacecraft, such as in Rendezvous with Rama.

Communication with Alien Intelligence ðŸ”—

Many stories deal with the challenges of communication. StanisÅ‚aw Lem’s works often portray mutual understanding between humans and aliens as impossible, criticizing the idea of cognitive universality.

Message from Space ðŸ”—

First contact may occur through the detection of an extraterrestrial signal or technosignature. The search for extraterrestrial intelligence (SETI) began with the advent of radio.

Alien Languages ðŸ”—

Languages are a common form of communication with aliens, and many stories explore language issues. While space operas often use universal translators, hard science fiction typically depicts the difficulties of communicating with aliens, which can lead to misunderstandings and even war.

Ethics of First Contact ðŸ”—

Many writers have considered how humans should treat aliens upon first contact. The Prime Directive of Star Trek is a notable example of non-interference. In Soviet science fiction, “progressors” worked clandestinely to improve less advanced civilizations.

Notable Examples ðŸ”—

The Day the Earth Stood Still ðŸ”—

Based on the short story “Farewell to the Master,” The Day the Earth Stood Still depicts the arrival of Klaatu and Gort in Washington, D.C. Humanity’s hostile response to first contact is used as an allegory for the Second Red Scare.

Close Encounters of the Third Kind ðŸ”—

This 1977 film by Steven Spielberg tells the story of Roy Neary, whose life changes after an encounter with a UFO. The film was deemed “culturally, historically, or aesthetically significant” by the Library of Congress.

Contact ðŸ”—

Carl Sagan’s 1985 novel, later adapted into a film, depicts the reception of a radio signal from Vega and the construction of a Machine based on the message’s specifications.

Star Trek ðŸ”—

First contact is central to Starfleet operations in the Star Trek franchise. The Prime Directive is a foundational regulation, though it is frequently violated.

Star Trek: The Original Series ðŸ”—

The original pilot episode features the Talosians. The Prime Directive was introduced in “The Return of the Archons” to prevent negative consequences from contact with technologically inferior societies.

Star Trek: The Next Generation ðŸ”—

The pilot episode, “Encounter at Farpoint,” depicts first contact with the Q Continuum. Episodes like “Who Watches the Watchers” and “First Contact” center on the Prime Directive.

Star Trek: First Contact ðŸ”—

This 1996 film portrays first contact between humans and Vulcans, leading to the formation of the United Federation of Planets.

The War of the Worlds ðŸ”—

H.G. Wells’ novel details a conflict between humankind and Martians. It has been adapted into numerous films, radio dramas, and other media. The 1938 radio drama, directed by Orson Welles, reportedly caused panic among listeners.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/First_contact_(science_fiction)

item.title: Alien Trespass (2009 Film)
item.description:
Alien Trespass (2009 Film) ðŸ”—

This is a description of the 2009 film Alien Trespass, directed by R.W. Goodwin. The film is a science-fiction comedy that pays homage to the B movies of the 1950s.

Plot ðŸ”—

The story is set in 1957 in California’s Mojave Desert. Astronomer Ted Lewis and his wife Lana are observing a meteor shower when something crashes nearby. Ted investigates and discovers an alien spaceship. His body is then taken over by Urp, a well-meaning alien who is searching for Ghota, a one-eyed monster that escaped from the ship. Ghota consumes people to grow and multiply, threatening Earth. Urp enlists the help of Tammy, a local waitress, to stop Ghota. The local police, Chief Dawson and Officer Vern, are skeptical. Urp and Tammy hunt down Ghota, and they eventually fall in love. At the end, Urp returns to his home planet, leaving Tammy to pursue her dreams.

Cast ðŸ”—

The film stars Eric McCormack as Ted Lewis/Urp, Jenni Baird as Tammy, Robert Patrick as Vernon, Jody Thompson as Lana Lewis, and Dan Lauria as Chief Dawson. Other cast members include Sarah Smyth, Aaron Brooks, Andrew Dunbar, Dayna Reid, Chelah Horsdal, Sage Brocklebank, Jonathon Young, and Tom McBeath.

Analysis ðŸ”—

The film replicates the look and feel of 1950s science fiction films, with the exception of being in color. The film uses the trope of monsters terrorizing small desert towns, which was common in 1950s B movies due to lower production costs. The character of Lana Lewis is depicted as a “sexpot,” a common archetype in 1950s science fiction films. The Ghota is similar to B.O.B. from Monsters vs. Aliens. The romance between Urp and Tammy is reminiscent of The Day the Earth Stood Still. Director Goodwin states that the film takes elements from The Day the Earth Stood Still, It Came from Outer Space, and The War of the Worlds.

Reception ðŸ”—

The film received mixed reviews. Rotten Tomatoes gives it a 38% approval rating, with the consensus being that it loses its charm due to tedious dialogue and cheesy special effects. Roger Ebert gave the film two out of four stars, stating that it was a labor of love but questioning whether there was a demand for cheesy 1950s sci-fi movies. Jeannette Catsoulis of The New York Times described the film as a charming but pointless homage. Betsy Sharkey of the Los Angeles Times felt that the film stayed too true to the era and genre, forgetting to entertain. IGN praised the film’s recreation of the 1950s aesthetic but found that it couldn’t decide whether to emulate or satirize the genre. Ty Burr of The Boston Globe felt that the film was superior to Monsters vs. Aliens. Entertainment Weekly gave the film a “B+” rating, praising its warm tone and anti-CGI look. Gary Westfahl considers the film an overlooked gem that captures the charm of 1950s science fiction films.

See also ðŸ”—

The article lists other films related to the genre, including Earth vs. the Flying Saucers, Forbidden Planet, Invaders from Mars, Mars Attacks!, and The Lost Skeleton of Cadavra.

Sources ðŸ”—

The article cites several sources, including reviews by Roger Ebert, Gary Westfahl, and articles from AMC.com.

References ðŸ”—

The article includes a list of references to support the information presented.

External links ðŸ”—

The article provides links to the film’s official website, IMDb page, Rotten Tomatoes page, TCM Movie Database page, and articles from The New York Times, AMCtv.com, and Starlog magazine.

item.title: Alien language in science fiction
item.description:
Alien language in science fiction ðŸ”—

This article discusses the concept of alien languages as portrayed in science fiction, tracing its development from early examples to more sophisticated and detailed implementations. It highlights how the treatment of alien languages has evolved alongside the science fiction genre itself.

Understanding alien languages ðŸ”—

This section explores the challenges and approaches to understanding alien languages in science fiction. It notes the common trope of universal translators in space operas, contrasting it with hard science fiction’s focus on the difficulties of interspecies communication. The section mentions C.S. Lewis’s Out of the Silent Planet, where the protagonist uses historical linguistics to decipher a Martian language. Stanislaw Lem’s His Master’s Voice is cited as a critical examination of humanity’s ability to understand extraterrestrial messages. D.R. Merrill’s Lamikorda emphasizes the importance of body language and cultural context in communication.

The section also discusses franchises that have developed their own languages, such as Klingon in Star Trek (created by Marc Okrand), the Zentradi language from Macross, Kryptonese from DC Comics, Cybertronian from Transformers, and Na’vi from Avatar (created by James Cameron with Paul Frommer).

The use of language as a plot device is explored, with examples like Star Trek VI: The Undiscovered Country, the Star Trek TNG episode “Darmok,” and the film Mars Attacks! The Babylon 5 episode “Into the Fire” illustrates how misunderstandings can arise from phonetic similarities between languages. C.J. Cherryh’s Chanur series and Foreigner universe are mentioned for their focus on linguistic and psychological barriers to communication. Conversely, The Simpsons is cited for its comedic take on the improbable mutual understanding of English by humans and aliens.

The section also references stories with unpronounceable alien tongues, such as Clark Ashton Smith’s tale featuring the sorcerer Eibon and the alien Hziulquoigmnzhah. Mary Doria Russell’s The Sparrow is mentioned for its complex alien language with unique tenses. Carl Sagan’s Contact is cited for its multilayered encrypted messages from extraterrestrials. Ted Chiang’s “Story of Your Life” (and its film adaptation, Arrival) is highlighted for its detailed portrayal of alien communication through complex symbols. Sheila Finch’s The Guild of Xenolinguists is mentioned as a collection of stories about first contact and alien communication.

Other examples include the Unitology language from the game Dead Space, Alienese from Futurama, and the R’lyehian/Cthuvian language from H.P. Lovecraft’s Cthulhu mythos. Robert Sheckley’s “Shall We Have a Little Talk?” describes a language that mutates too rapidly to be learned. China MiÃ©ville’s Embassytown features the Ariekei language, which requires speakers to use two words at once, spoken by genetically engineered human twins.

Bypassing the issue of language ðŸ”—

This section examines how some science fiction avoids the complexities of alien languages through various devices and concepts.

Universal translators ðŸ”—

This subsection focuses on devices that seamlessly translate between languages, effectively eliminating language barriers. Examples include Douglas Adams’s babel fish, the TARDIS from Doctor Who, the translator microbes in Farscape, and the universal translator from Star Trek.

Universal language ðŸ”—

This subsection discusses the concept of a common language shared by multiple species. Star Wars uses Basic as a universal language. Other examples include Interlac from the Legion of Super-Heroes, Babylon 5, and the Uplift Universe, where multiple “Galactic” languages are used. Stargate SG-1 features a galactic meeting place where races communicate using a language based on atomic structures.

Telepathy ðŸ”—

This subsection explores the use of telepathy as a means of communication. The Vulcans in Star Trek use the Vulcan mind meld. In Ender’s Game, the Buggers communicate telepathically through their queen, highlighting the communication barriers between species.

See also ðŸ”—

This section provides links to related Wikipedia articles, including “Alien language” and “Astrolinguistics.”

References ðŸ”—

This section lists the sources cited in the article, including academic papers, books, and websites.

External links ðŸ”—

This section provides a link to an external resource: “A Primer In SF XENOLINGUISTICS” by Justin B. Rye.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alien_language_in_science_fiction

item.title: Storm Area 51
item.description:
Storm Area 51 ðŸ”—

Storm Area 51 was a Facebook event and internet meme that gained widespread attention in 2019. It centered around the idea of raiding Area 51, a highly classified United States Air Force facility, in search of extraterrestrial life.

Background ðŸ”—

Area 51 is a United States Air Force facility within the Nevada Test and Training Range. It opened in 1955 and functioned as an aircraft testing and development facility during the Cold War. Due to its intense secrecy, Area 51 has become the subject of conspiracy theories regarding the presence of aliens. These theories began in the 1950s, with some individuals reporting UFO sightings at the base. Conspiracy theorists believe aliens, UFOs, or related information are stored at Area 51.

Facebook event and Internet meme ðŸ”—

Matty Roberts, a Bakersfield resident and moderator of the Facebook page Shitposting cause I’m in shambles, created the Storm Area 51 event. He devised the idea after watching Area 51 conspiracy theorist Bob Lazar and filmmaker Jeremy Corbell on The Joe Rogan Experience podcast. The event was planned to take place in Amargosa Valley on September 20, 2019. The Facebook event page included the phrase “If we Naruto run, we can move faster than their bullets. Lets see them aliens.” The event quickly went viral, spreading to other social media platforms. The event received 2 million “going” and 1.5 million “interested” signatures. Rapper Lil Nas X released a music video for the remix of “Old Town Road” about the planned raid. Copycat events were also created, such as plans to storm a genealogical vault of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, Loch Ness, the Bermuda Triangle, the US Capitol Building, and the Vatican City’s archives.

Response ðŸ”—

National government ðŸ”—

Air Force spokeswoman Laura McAndrews stated that officials were aware of the event and issued a warning against attempting to enter the area. The FBI also stated that they would be monitoring the situation. The FAA posted temporary flight restrictions, closing the airspace above two places nearby Area 51. The DVIDS made a Twitter post depicting military personnel and a B-2 stealth bomber with a controversial caption, which was later deleted, and an apology was issued.

Local government ðŸ”—

Lincoln County officials drafted an emergency declaration and a plan to pool resources with neighboring counties, anticipating a large crowd. Concerns were raised about the limited number of hotel rooms, cellphone network capacity, and overcrowding at campsites, gas stations, and medical facilities. The town of Rachel posted a caution on its website, advising attendees to be experienced in desert survival and warning that the town would likely be unable to provide sufficient resources.

Businesses ðŸ”—

Business owners in and around Rachel, Nevada, made preparations for visitors. Connie West, co-owner of the Little A’Le’Inn, booked all rooms and planned to open up camping space. Las Vegas businessman George Harris planned to hire bands for a festival called “The Swarm.” Other businesses around the U.S. based products and services on the event. Bud Light planned to release a promotional alien-themed beer label. Arby’s had planned to deliver food with a special menu to the event.

Gathering and music festivals ðŸ”—

While the event was intended as comedic, some took it seriously and traveled to areas surrounding the facility. The Lincoln County Sheriff estimated that about 1,500 people showed up at the festivals, while about 150 people made the journey to the back gate of Area 51. One person attempted to enter the facility and received a warning, while six others were arrested for various offenses. Two people were injured in a rollover crash near Rachel.

Two music festivals were announced: Alienstock in Rachel, Nevada, and Storm Area 51 Basecamp in Hiko, Nevada. Event creator Roberts pulled out of Alienstock 10 days before the festival, citing poor planning, and joined an alien-themed party in Las Vegas. Roberts’s lawyers sent a cease and desist regarding use of the name to Little A’Le’Inn owner Connie West, who continued with the name Alienstock in Rachel, Nevada. After the raid, the Area 51 Basecamp event was deemed a failure, while Alienstock was considered a success. The event’s aftermath saw several pending lawsuits surrounding the festival and Roberts’s call to breach the government facility.

item.title: Aliens in the Family (1996 TV series)
item.description:
Aliens in the Family (1996 TV series) ðŸ”—

Aliens in the Family is an American science fantasy sitcom that aired on ABC from March 15 to August 31, 1996. It was created by Andy and Susan Borowitz and was part of ABC’s TGIF lineup.

Premise ðŸ”—

The show centers around Doug Brody, a single father, who is abducted by Cookie, a single alien mother. They fall in love, get married, and attempt to live a normal life on Earth as a blended family.

Cast ðŸ”—

The main cast includes:

  • John Bedford Lloyd as Doug Brody
  • Margaret Trigg as Cookie Brody
  • Paige Tiffany as Heather Brody
  • Chris Marquette as Adam Brody
  • Julie Dretzin as Sally Hagen

The show also features several puppeteers who brought the alien characters to life:

  • Alice Dinnean as Snizzy (face and voice)
  • Michael Gilden as Snizzy (body)
  • John Kennedy as Bobut (face)
  • Bruce Lanoil as Spit (face)
  • Peter Linz as Varch, Elder of the Nertron Galactic Federation, Red Yukkle
  • Joey Mazzarino as Spit (voice), Green and Yellow Yukkles
  • David Rudman as Bobut (body and voice), Orange and Purple Yukkles
  • Michelan Sisti as Spit (body)

Production ðŸ”—

Andy and Susan Borowitz created, wrote, and executive produced the series. Brian Henson, son of Jim Henson, served as co-executive producer. Todd Rundgren wrote and performed the theme song. The series was filmed entirely at Lifetime Studios in New York City.

Episodes ðŸ”—

The show had one season consisting of eight episodes:

  1. “Meet the Brodys” (March 15, 1996)
  2. “Bobut Conquers All” (March 22, 1996)
  3. “Cookie Makes Some Dough” (July 27, 1996)
  4. “You Don’t Have a Pet to Be Popular” (August 3, 1996)
  5. “Too Good to Be True” (August 10, 1996)
  6. “Respect Your Elders” (August 17, 1996)
  7. “Dissected and Neglected” (August 24, 1996)
  8. “A Very Brody Tweeznax” (August 31, 1996)

Cancellation ðŸ”—

ABC canceled the show from its TGIF lineup after only two weeks. The remaining episodes aired on Saturday mornings during the summer of 1996.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aliens_in_the_Family
